body: This is a bug, and I currently get around it by using a partial for the view.

Thank you.
I hope this can be fixed soon.

Do you know what the bug is, exactly? It sounds like something I ran into a couple weeks ago while trying to write some tests, where f.object seemed like it did not consistently point to the right instance. I wasn't able to hunt down the issue, and it would be great to get some perspective on what's actually going on.
I have no idea what is going wrong.  It seems like an important bug.
I don't think it has anything to do with `f.object` - I'm almost positive it has to do with the `ActiveAdmin::FormBuilder` form buffering.
That was as far as I got, too. I think the f.object problem may have been a red herring, as I initially forgot accepts_nested_attributes_for in my model. For shame!

Has anyone found another workaround other than using a partial?

I tried the partial method, but then you lose the f.has_many method, as it's part of active_admin_form_for and not semantic_form_for

so I don't want to use the partial, I'd rather stick with the form block

This is what I want to do, show the delete field if object is already saved

``` ruby
f.has_many :jobs do |job|
  job.input :store
  job.input :department
  job.input :position
  unless job.object.new_record?
    job.input(:_destroy, :as => :boolean, :label => "Delete this job")
  end
end
```

However, because of the way the form block buffers the output, I cannot for the life of me get it to work

This will work, but it's in the wrong place!

``` ruby
f.has_many :jobs do |job|
  unless job.object.new_record?
    job.input(:_destroy, :as => :boolean, :label => "Delete this job")
  end
  job.input :store
  job.input :department
  job.input :position
end
```

That's interesting - does it work when you put it first because the form buffer hasn't been tampered with? Could you do:

``` ruby
f.has_many :jobs do |job|
  record = job.object
  job.input :store
  job.input :department
  job.input :position
  unless record.new_record?
    job.input(:_destroy, :as => :boolean, :label => "Delete this job")
  end
end
```

I'm not able to test this now, or I wouldn't ask something so simple!

I came up with this... it seems to work.

``` ruby
f.has_many :jobs do |job|
  job.input :store
  job.input :department
  buffer = job.input :position
  unless job.object.new_record?
    job.input(:_destroy, :as => :boolean, :label => "Delete this job")
  end
  buffer
end
```

the issue is with the last if statement returning a value.  By returning the "buffer" at the end, it works correctly.

That's great. I wonder if we can confirm if that's the problem everyone is running into on this issue. It seems we should be able to avoid requiring the method to return the form buffer, so you don't need to resort to that.

I'm experiencing something similar:

``` ruby
f.inputs "Details" do
  f.input :url, :as => :string
  if f.object.new_record?
    # do something
  end
end
```

`url` won't show up in new record mode. If I add something below the new_record? end statement, then things work as expected.

issue.title: Fix FormBuilder#inputs content capturing

repository.name: activeadmin
repository.description: The administration framework for Ruby on Rails applications.

issue.body:
Without this change this would return an empty fieldset

``` ruby
ActiveAdmin.register Member do
  form do |f|
    f.inputs 'Authentication' do
      f.input :email

      # when the following is false the block returns nil
      unless f.object.persisted?
        f.input :password
        f.input :password_confirmation
      end
    end
  end  
end
```

**edit:**

A quick workaround (yet not definitive), thanks to @thbar:

``` ruby
ActiveAdmin.register Member do
  form do |f|
    f.inputs 'Authentication' do
      f.input :email

      # when the following is false the block returns nil
      unless f.object.persisted?
        f.input :password
        f.input :password_confirmation
      end
      f.form_buffers.last # <<< add this
    end
  end  
end
```

body: Yeah, the inputs block is expecting you to return the form buffer. It would be nice if that weren't required.
This can't be a duplicate of #965 since it's a PR and this Issue existed before it did.

issue.title: Conditional field in has_many nested form doesn't work if it's the last field

repository.name: activeadmin
repository.description: The administration framework for Ruby on Rails applications.

issue.body:
I have a model:

``` ruby
class Parent < ActiveRecord::Base
  has_many :children
end
```

And a form:

``` ruby
form do |f|
  f.inputs do
    f.has_many :children do |child_f|
      child_f.input :name
      child_f.input :_destroy, :as => :boolean, :label => "Remove" unless child_f.object.new_record?
    end
  end
end
```

When the form is loaded, I get the error:

```
undefined method `+' for nil:NilClass
```

However, if that `unless` line is moved to any other position in the block, no error shows up and everything works just fine.

issue.title: [887] Respect the form buffer!

repository.name: activeadmin
repository.description: The administration framework for Ruby on Rails applications.

issue.body:
resolves #887

All it took:

``` ruby
# This method calls the block it's passed (in our case, the `f.inputs` block)
# and wraps the resulting HTML in a fieldset. If your block happens to return
# nil (but it otherwise built the form correctly), the below override passes
# the most recent part of the Active Admin form buffer.
def field_set_and_list_wrapping(*args, &block)
  block_given? ? super{ yield || form_buffers.last } : super
end
```
